notes: Fourth-generation Mazda3 features SkyActiv-Vehicle Architecture with human-centric design philosophy. Turbo variants available on hatchback body style only. AWD available with 2.5L naturally aspirated engine. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda3 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Final years of Mazda6 in North American market. Third-generation model discontinued after 2021 model year. Turbo engine optional on Grand Touring Reserve and Signature trims. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda6 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Subcompact crossover SUV built on SkyActiv-Vehicle Architecture. Positioned between CX-3 and CX-5 in lineup. Turbo engine available starting 2021 model year on higher trims. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-30 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation CX-5 received refresh for 2022 model year with updated exterior styling and interior technology. Turbo engine optional on higher trims. Most popular Mazda model in North America. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation CX-9 is largest Mazda crossover sold in North America. Uses turbocharged four-cylinder engine instead of V6 from previous generation. Three-row seating for up to seven passengers. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-9 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fourth-generation MX-5 Miata received power increase to 181 hp for 2019+ models. Available in soft-top roadster or RF (Retractable Fastback) with power hardtop. Maintains traditional front-engine, rear-wheel-drive sports car layout. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MX-5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Battery electric vehicle with 35.5 kWh battery pack providing approximately 100 miles of range. Limited availability in California only. Features freestyle rear-hinged doors. Discontinued in North America after 2023. Difficulty modifier reflects EV-specific service requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MX-30 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Compact crossover SUV built at Mazda Toyota Manufacturing USA plant in Alabama. More rugged styling than CX-5 with higher ground clearance and off-road capability. Does not replace CX-5, sold alongside it. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-50 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Two-row midsize crossover based on Large Product Group platform with longitudinal engine layout. Features Mazda's return to inline-six engines and RWD-based architecture. PHEV variant uses 2.5L four-cylinder with electric motor and 17.8 kWh battery. Difficulty modifier reflects PHEV high-voltage system service requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-70 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Three-row midsize crossover based on Large Product Group platform with longitudinal engine layout. Replaces CX-9 as flagship crossover. Features Mazda's return to inline-six engines and RWD-based architecture. PHEV variant uses 2.5L four-cylinder with electric motor and 17.8 kWh battery. Difficulty modifier reflects PHEV high-voltage system service requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-90 article, December 19, 2024 revision.
